Deftux
Feature Stub

Recent:

Day 80 - Lucidchart's Preview

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When someone sends you a template from Lucidchart, it adds in a small gif that shows you all of the screens available in the template.

Why it’s good: This particular decision is so smart because it answers a very human question: “What is this?” In this particular case, the coworker who sent this to me hadn’t told me they were sending me something.

Instead of requiring some leap of faith, Lucidchart gave me a smart preview that let me know what I would find when I opened the template. Also, I’m not entirely sure how they worked this out, but the image that showed the screens wasn’t blocked by Outlook initially, so I saw the preview even in my inbox’s default state.

Predicting the questions that people ask isn’t easy, but it adds so much value to a product. “What is this?” is especially important when dealing with notification emails, or other messages that weren’t initiated by user action.

Day 79 - Keynote's Animation Builder

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When animating elements on a slide in Keynote, you can open a “Build Order” control that lets you preview the animations, reorder them, and edit them quickly.

Why it’s good: A constant design goal of mine is balancing granularity with mass editing tools. Allowing flexibility while clearly indicating what is possible is incredibly valuable.

In this case, Keynote gives you an immensely powerful and flexible animation structure without locking you into a single method of working with it. Animations are created on the element level, tweaking functions and setting the build order via a dropdown in the right information panel. It’s useful, but very specific to the individual elements and doesn’t give you a sense of the slide as a whole.

This interface gives you that high-level view, allowing you to focus specifically on the animation order and methods at a slide level. The “Preview” button is brilliantly implemented, showing you an accurate representation of slide state and also showing you when and how the animations are happening. Selecting the animations for the individual elements also selects the element on the stage, showing you which element you are engaging with.

Day 78 - Chrome's Non Closure

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When you tap command + q in Chrome, it doesn’t instantly close the app. Instead, it displays a banner which says “Hold ⌘Q to quit.”

Why it’s good: As a enthusiastic browser tab user, I am consistently hitting command + w to close tabs. Small challenge: next to the “w” on a keyboard is the “q,” and the system default for OSX is to quit the entire application when command + q is pressed. This usually means attempting to recover the ~30 or so sites that I have open at any given time. It was a consistent issue before Chrome introduced this feature.

This approach works because of its internal logic (i.e. you usually hit the wrong key when you’re in a hurry, so we can assume you won’t be holding it down) and the consistent message. Instead of just preventing the action, the system tells you why nothing happened when you pressed your key combination.

Day 77 - Eater's Synopsis

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: For their feature length articles, Eater provides a synopsis with footnotes that link to the sections of the story.

Why it’s good: We operate in an attention economy. The first time that I ever saw a feature like this, it was on a major news site. They condensed the article into a few bullet points, which allowed me to form a strong opinion without actually reading the nuance of the text. Not exactly encouraging the best behavior.

This approach is so valuable because it offers a way to process the full article. It is more than just an overview, it’s also an index that gives me the structure of the article and what information I’ll find inside. The visually loud and important footnotes encourage interaction and exploration, and the smooth scroll effect gives me an overview of the article as I pan back and forth between the overview and the text.

Instead of just stripping meaning from the text, Eater gives the user the ability to choose what they want to see and allows a combination of browsing and reading.

Day 76 - Fitnotes' Timer

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: In the Fitnotes tracking app, saving a set starts a configurable timer.

Why it’s good: Frequently, really useful features are quite simple. Timing a break on saving a set is a pretty simple idea.

What makes this good is the flexibility and customization available. The time is easily changed, as are the notification settings. It verifies in triplicate that a timer has started. (The clock starts, the green banner slides down, and a notification appears) It also isn’t demanding about how you use the timer, but instead feeds the action into an existing feature.
